description: Early 19th century, from Afrikaans spoor, from Dutch spoor (“track”).
Akin to Old English and Old Norse spor (whence Danish spor), and German Spur, all from Proto-Germanic *spurą. Compare spurn.

entries.meaning: The track, trail, droppings or scent of an animal.
examples: Now he has picked up the spoor of drunken vomit and there is the doll sprawled against a wall, his pants streaked with urine.

verbs.description: spoor (third-person singular simple present spoors, present participle spooring, simple past and past participle spoored)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To track an animal by following its spoor
